ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Great overview of democracy past, present, and future as well as the role of democracy in some of our nations most important rights and institutions
I learned a lot about democracy as a political method and how changes in today's world are affecting democracies in North America and Europe.
Lots of work on clear, concise writing and engaging with a vast array of sources, topics, ideas, etc.
Improved my writing skills and critical thinking skills. Learned a lot in-depth about different facets of democracy. I also got more comfortable speaking in class.
I learned a lot about democracy and its intersections both in the US and internationally.
How to make well formulated arguments both in class and in essays.

A deep understanding of Western (European and American) political systems and how the erosion of liberal democracy has impacted the people of these nations. The course is very thorough in its investigation of said themes.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Dr. Young is an amazing professor. No weaknesses.

Strengths: class diversity and professor knowledge inspired excellent class discussion every week 

Weaknesses: lots of reading and those readings were often not discussed in class (but Im still glad I did them!)

Dr. Young is fantastic! I loved that she brought in guest speakers to converse with us, and the discussions and readings were fascinating and related well to current events. The workload is very manageable, and you'll learn a lot about democratic institutions from a comparative standpoint

Its hard to call this a weakness, because the course is so great as-is, but it sometimes feels like there could be room for more involvement with the readings. Usually, class has a great mix of current events and topical discussions. At the same time, office hours are a great place to talk about the readings, so its not really a weakness of the course so much as an endorsement of how full it is with engaging information.
The class always offered high quality discussions, but a few discussions on specific case studies could have enhanced the discussions.

strengths: Dr. Young!!!! An amazing, thorough professor who truly cares about her students, their lives, etc, way beyond teaching. That was refreshing and much needed, especially during the rough online semester. Content and readings were also a strengthreadings were kind of long but very thoughtfully selected for each topic. we also had great guest speakers who were really interesting and wanted to engage with us. We also received copious feedback on essays, which was super helpful and just again, showed how dedicated Dr. Young is to her students. talking about current events that related to democracy at the beginning of each class was something I also enjoyed. Weaknesses: none come to mind
Really strong in its rate of participation and opportunities for students to learn from one another.
It would have been amazing in person to meet Dr. Young and the other students, but other than that the course was amazing.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I loved the way we interacted in this course, and in Dr. Young's office hours, despite the pandemic. I just really hope next semester is in person classes, because even with the best efforts for engagement and learning, it is still really tough online.
The use of the hand-raising function in Zoom was really helpful in our learning.
IT was a seminar held over zoom, no need for improvement as other software or precautions would have been redundant.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! Dr. Young is knowledgeable and really cares about her students. She also takes the time to provide good feedback on essays which is often hard to come by in non-english classes. Class discussion is always engaging and readings/topics are interesting to anyone with even some interest in democracy/American/EU politics and policy.
I would recommend this course to anyone who wants a better understanding of the challenges facing democracies around the world today.
100%! One of my favorite classes so far, and Dr. Young is really invested in her students and wants to make sure that everyone is being challenged!

Yes! This course offers a very interesting combination of relevant (and very well selected) reading, discussions, and treatment of important current events in the world. Papers are open-ended questions about key topics, though they do involve independent research.

YES!!! please take the course if you are interested in the content. Dr. Young is one of the best profs i've had, if not the best. she is so passionate and kind and smart and will support you, challenge you, and open your eyes to different topics and perspectives.
Yes! Learned so much from my classmates and professor in comfortable setting.
Yes! Dr. Young is AMAZING and the other students were also very engaging.

If you want to do the readings consistently and be held accountable by class discussion, do not take this course. While students sometimes bring in the readings, the class discussions are mostly focused on overarching questions posed by Prof. Young that are informed by the readings. As someone who much prefers reading-based discussion that will flow into greater themes, I didn't like this aspect of the course and it hindered by learning when students would steer the discussion to the superficial rather than bringing in the complex analyses of the readings (which are very good).

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Virtual seminar and discussion
It was strictly a seminar, with several guest speakers.
